No one knows this, no one even thinks of it. Canada, one of the two closest countries to the United States. Canada is made up mostly of british decents, but there is a large province made up mostly of french called Quebec. This province has pushed to become a separate country for a long time and you occasionally still here about it in Canada (I know I lived there) Anyways, does anyone think of Quebec? The only reason they're still part of Canada is cause of all the money the canadian government is giving them. Will France take this opportunity is "liberate" these ancestors of france? Will France use Quebec to attack the U.S.?
 Think about it

 
 You lived there so you would know better than me, but I get the impression that Quebec's French culture is much different than that of France and that although they share a common language with France their languages are different in many ways and they don't always see eye to eye with France.
 
 As for Quebec attacking the US, I can't say that I've even considered this as a possibility. I think Quebec would have a tough time breaking away from Canada for starters and I don't think they would be much of a world power without the force of Canada behind them. Remember, Iraq over seas fell to us in a few months. Quebec is a few miles across our border and they are surrounded by parts of Canada which wouldn't be too happy with them both seceding from Canada or ruining relations with the US. Quebec would be insane to attack the US just because of the backing of France. Also, Quebec has a population of only 7.2 million. They are not going to be able to put up too much of a fight in a conventional war.
 
 If you want to at least make a realistic case here you will have to make another Cuban missile crisis out of it. France would have to ship their nuclear weapons over to Quebec and threaten to use them against the US. That is about all that Quebec would be good for if France wanted to invade the US.

 True. All nations do look after their own interests. I don't mind so much that France was against the war in Iraq as it wasn't in their interest for it to happen. France was making money of the Iraq that was in place before the war. However, now it is in Frances best interests to help the US to get Iraq stabilized. It would improve political relations between the two countries and it would allow France to have some room to negotiate Iraqi contracts in the future. But France is holding a grudge. They don't seem to care what is best for them, the US, and the people of Iraq right now. I don't think they are acting like an ally of the US at this time and it isn't just because it is in their interest to act this way.
 
 
Keeping that in mind... if you want a more rational reason why France didn't actively help... and for why the US attacked when it did (given it was some time after the weapons inspectors had been booted out)
 
 Iraq was planning on switiching their payments of oil from US dollars to Euros.
 
 If one of the world's biggest oil producers started trading in Euros instead of US dollars it would lessen the power of the dollar as the unofficial world currency.
 
 Germany and France, the chief powers behind the Euros were both adamant that the US should stay out of Iraq.

 
 I don't like the fact that the Euro and US dollar caused a rift between the EU and the US but I'm sure this played a role in the events leading up to the war. France not backing the US wasn't a big surprise to me although they seemed pretty aggressive about it, much more so than Germany. The continunance of this aggression is what is getting to me.
 
 
Hey, have they found those weapons of mass destruction yet?
 That's one of the biggest con-jobs ever.
 
 They had tonnes of 'evidence' (photos) of the Iraqiis storing weapons... but when they got to the sites it was gone... how come there was not a single photo of the Iraqiis unloading the stuff into a new site?

 
 Many still think we will find WMDs. I'm not convinced they are there anymore but they still could be.
 
 If they are not though then someone has to be made to pay for this mistake. The president was basing his decisions on information from other sources and those sources have to be made known and punished for their mistakes.
 
 I think the WMDs was also just a reason to go into a country that we already knew needed to be attacked to make a broader statement. First off we needed to take away their threat to Israel so we could get them talking about an agreement with the Palestinians. Second, we wanted to have a place to station our forces in the Middle East. Third, we wanted our forces on the border of Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Syria to help fight terrorism and influence politics there in the future. Fourth, I have no doubt oil played a role in this invasion. Fifth, I think Bush did it to score some popularity points and to take the focus off his failure to catch Osama. I'm sure there are more reasons but I think these are the biggest reasons other than to prevent Iraq from making or using WMDs in the future.

 Partly answering the point. France was in need from 1914-1917, and 1939-1941 before you intervened. You did so, not to 'aid' France, but because it was in you national interest to go to war when you did, otherwise you'd have been involved earlier. And you didn't get involved at all in 1870!
 
 I am not at all arguing aginst America or pro-France, but trying to put things into persepective, re: nations look after their own first. I've yet to find a nation's foreign policy built on altruistism.*
 
 
Why didn't France help? France, about 20% of Iraqi oil. 8 billion dollars over the last few years in profit. One of Iraq's largest trading partners, and one of its biggest lenders. They also helped illegally rearm Iraq after 1991.

 
 So America helped 'legally' arm Iraq. When G W Bush called Sadaam a monster, (which he is/was) some of the evidence cited was that he gassed his own people, viz the Kurds. This was when he was your ally.
 
 
 *An interesting footnote to WWII. When France fell to the Germans, the Brits were worried that the French fleet would fall into the German's hands... an action that would have drastically changed the power in the Mediterranean. They urged the French to sail their ships to North Africa, or to a neutral port. The French declined. So, the Brits had to (in their own national interest) take a drastic measure, they sailed into port and bombarded the French fleet whilst it was still at anchor.
 The French retaliated with a few minor raids on Gibraltar.
 
 All of this happening when they are supposed to be allies!
 
 Early in the war Australia invaded the French colony of New Caledonia to deny it to the Japanese (who had already put pressure on colonial officals in French Indo-China to let them run the show there)
 
 As well, my own grand-father fought French forces in WWII. He was part of the 6th Australian Division which was sent to Syria to fight Vichy French (pro-German) forces.
 
 So I am in no way pro-France.

 Are you aware of the illogic argument you just made. France is part of the UN Security Council. They had a right to vote. It's like saying the 'UN would have been involved had the UN voted for it'! Of course they'd have been involved, but they didn't vote for involvement in a war, so they're not involved!
 
 It is the process of the UN for a UN member to vote! You can't say "We support the UN, but we don't support the vote that they took because one of more members didn't vote the way we wanted". It's absurd.
 
 
We've always wanted the UN involved. Bush has always said the UN should play a part. The question is do you want to turn it into an East Timor or leave it under the US CPA?

 In the mid-1970s a change in government in Portugal meant the off-loading of almost all their colonies... Anglola, Mozambique, East Timore etc.
 East Timor made moves for independence, but ashamedly Australia and the USA gave the nod to Indonesia to take over - alledging that the East Timorese were going to go communist.
 From 1975 they were a persecuted group of mainly Christians, in the largest Muslim nation on earth.
 
 If you want another example... Irian Jaya, or West Irian, is part of the same island as Papua New Guinea. It wasn't part of the newly formed republic of Indonesia in 1945, because the Dutch wanted it to become a separate nation... seeing as the population aren't Asian, but Melanesian. Then in the 1960s the USA sponsored the Indonesians taking over, so they could open up the huge Freeport mine there. The people are either Christian or animists, they have nothing in common with Indonesia, and they want independence. What is the USA doing about it? Nothing, so long as the mine stays open, they're happy.
